situations.name: At the Café
situations.description: Cafes are social hubs in Saigon. Ordering confidently in Vietnamese will earn you smiles and sometimes free upgrades to your drink.
situations.culturalNote: Vietnamese coffee culture is sacred. Taking time to sit and sip is expected—rushing is seen as odd. Sidewalk cafes with tiny plastic stools are often better than fancy ones.

phrases.whenToUse: Your essential coffee order—this is the default
phrases.culturalTip: This is Southern Vietnamese iced coffee with condensed milk. It's sweet, strong, and addictive.

phrases.whenToUse: If you want coffee without milk
phrases.culturalTip: Add 'đá' (da) for iced, 'nóng' (nong) for hot

phrases.whenToUse: When your drink needs more ice in the heat
phrases.culturalTip: Ice is free and plentiful—asking for more is normal
This phrase makes people smile instantly

phrases.whenToUse: Ordering the famous Hanoi-style egg coffee (also popular in Saigon)
phrases.culturalTip: Creamy, sweet, and rich—like a coffee dessert

phrases.whenToUse: A Southern specialty—coffee with coconut milk
phrases.culturalTip: Refreshing and tropical, perfect for hot days
Most cafes have wifi—password is often on the wall or menu
Sometimes it's just the phone number of the cafe

phrases.vietnamese: Cho tôi ngồi đây được không?
phrases.pronunciation: Cho toy ngoy day doo-oc khom?
phrases.literal: Give me sit here can or not?
phrases.whenToUse: Asking if a table/seat is available
phrases.culturalTip: Cafes can get crowded—asking shows politeness

situations.name: In a Taxi / Grab
situations.description: Most rides are via Grab app now, but knowing these phrases helps with communication and shows respect.
situations.culturalNote: Grab is everywhere and safe. Traditional taxis can overcharge tourists—use the meter or stick with Grab. Drivers appreciate any Vietnamese attempt.

phrases.culturalTip: Have the address written in Vietnamese or show on phone

phrases.whenToUse: When you've arrived or want to stop
phrases.culturalTip: Point as you say it for clarity

phrases.whenToUse: Asking the price (though Grab shows it upfront)
phrases.culturalTip: With Grab you don't need this, but useful for traditional taxis
Use 'anh' for male drivers, 'chị' (chee) for female drivers
Point as you say it for extra clarity
Most drivers follow GPS now, but this helps in complex areas

phrases.whenToUse: When you want them to continue straight
phrases.culturalTip: Combine with hand gestures for best results

phrases.whenToUse: If the driver is going too fast for comfort
phrases.culturalTip: Say it politely—Saigon traffic moves fast but safety first

phrases.whenToUse: If you need the driver to wait briefly
phrases.culturalTip: Show your phone/watch to indicate how long

phrases.vietnamese: Đi sân bay Tân Sơn Nhất
phrases.pronunciation: Dee sun buy Tan Sun Nyat
phrases.english: Go to Tan Son Nhat Airport
phrases.culturalTip: Airport is about 30-40 minutes from District 1

situations.name: At a Restaurant
situations.description: Street food stalls and local restaurants are where Vietnamese shines. These phrases will enhance your eating experience immensely.
situations.culturalNote: Pointing at menu items or what others are eating is totally acceptable. Food culture is casual and welcoming. Don't expect fast service—meals are social, not rushed.

phrases.whenToUse: Ordering food at stalls or restaurants
phrases.culturalTip: Point at what you want as you say this

phrases.whenToUse: If you can't handle heat—VERY useful
phrases.culturalTip: Vietnamese food isn't super spicy compared to Thai, but this helps
May need to call the server over first with 'Em ơi!' (em oy - excuse me)

phrases.whenToUse: Complimenting the food—makes vendors incredibly happy
phrases.culturalTip: This phrase creates instant warmth and often leads to conversations
Point at the dish and ask—people love explaining their food
Vietnam has great vegetarian food—look for 'cơm chay' restaurants

phrases.whenToUse: If you want to avoid MSG
phrases.culturalTip: MSG is common in Vietnamese cooking—this requests without
Usually they bring bottled water—tap water isn't safe to drink

phrases.english: What's good here? / What do you recommend?
phrases.culturalTip: Locals love sharing their favorites—leads to best discoveries
Most places have them, but sometimes you need to ask
Standard way to get attention—not rude at all

phrases.whenToUse: If you want some spice but not too much
phrases.culturalTip: Vietnamese usually add chili sauce themselves at the table

situations.name: Greetings & Politeness
situations.description: Vietnamese greetings depend on age and gender. These basics will serve you well and show respect.
situations.culturalNote: Age hierarchy is important in Vietnam. Using the right pronoun (anh/chi/em) shows cultural awareness and earns respect. When in doubt, use anh (for men) or chi (for women) for people who look older than you.

phrases.whenToUse: General greeting, safe in any situation
phrases.culturalTip: Add 'anh' (male) or 'chị' (female) after for more respect: 'Xin chào anh'
Can add 'nhiều' (nyew) for 'thank you very much': Cảm ơn nhiều
Works for both 'sorry' and 'excuse me'—context makes it clear
Literally means 'no star' but means 'no worries'—very common phrase
More casual: 'Chào anh/chị' (just 'chao an/chee') works for bye too
Use 'anh/chị' instead of 'bạn' for older people
Follow up with 'còn bạn?' (còn ban?) meaning 'and you?'

phrases.literal: Very happy be able meet you
phrases.whenToUse: Meeting someone for the first time
phrases.culturalTip: Smile when you say this—warmth goes far

phrases.english: See you later / See you again
phrases.whenToUse: Casual goodbye when you'll see them again
phrases.culturalTip: More casual than 'tạm biệt' and friendlier
Sweet phrase—literally wishing someone 'delicious sleep'

phrases.whenToUse: When you need to squeeze past someone
phrases.culturalTip: Essential in crowded markets and streets

situations.name: Shopping & Markets
situations.description: Markets are social spaces. Bargaining is expected in some (like Ben Thanh) but not all. These phrases help navigate.
situations.culturalNote: Bargaining is an art in Vietnam. Smile, be friendly, and don't be aggressive. Fixed-price shops are becoming more common, especially in malls. When in doubt, ask if price can be negotiated.

phrases.culturalTip: First price at tourist markets is often 2-3x actual—bargain politely

phrases.whenToUse: When bargaining—say it with a smile
phrases.culturalTip: Part of the dance—they expect this response
Works better than demanding—Vietnamese appreciate politeness

phrases.whenToUse: When you've agreed on a price
phrases.culturalTip: Point at the item as you say it

phrases.whenToUse: Asking to try on clothes or test something
phrases.culturalTip: Many small shops let you try things—just ask politely
Vendors often have stock in back—worth asking

phrases.english: Do you have a bigger size?
phrases.whenToUse: When you need a larger size
phrases.culturalTip: Vietnamese sizes run smaller—don't be shy to ask

phrases.whenToUse: Asking if they take credit/debit cards
phrases.culturalTip: Many small vendors are cash only—have dong ready
Point as you say it—vendors are happy to show you items

phrases.whenToUse: Asking if the price is fixed or negotiable
phrases.culturalTip: Many modern shops have fixed prices—bargaining isn't always expected

situations.name: Emergency & Help
situations.description: Hope you never need these, but knowing them provides peace of mind.
situations.culturalNote: Vietnamese people are generally very helpful to foreigners in distress. Don't hesitate to ask for help—'Xin lỗi' (excuse me) followed by simple English often works too.

phrases.culturalTip: Wave your arms, look distressed—people will assist
Show Google Translate or point to phone—hospitals have English speakers
Pointing and saying 'WC' also works—universal sign

phrases.whenToUse: When you can't find your way
phrases.culturalTip: Show your phone with destination—people will help or call you a Grab

phrases.whenToUse: When you're confused or lost in translation
phrases.culturalTip: Follow with hand gestures—people will find a way to communicate

phrases.whenToUse: When someone is speaking too fast
phrases.culturalTip: Locals are patient with learners—don't be shy to ask

phrases.whenToUse: Looking for someone who speaks English
phrases.culturalTip: Many young people speak some English—especially in tourist areas

phrases.whenToUse: When you need assistance with something
phrases.culturalTip: Vietnamese people are generally very helpful to foreigners
Police number is 113—hopefully you never need it

situations.name: Numbers & Money
situations.description: Understanding Vietnamese numbers is crucial for shopping, taxis, and daily transactions. These basics will help you navigate prices and payments.
situations.culturalNote: Vietnamese dong has lots of zeros (20,000 = about $1). Get comfortable with thousands. Vendors will often show you numbers on a calculator to avoid confusion.

phrases.culturalTip: Foundation for all numbers—master this first
Pronounced like English 'high'
Simple and straightforward
Watch the tone—different from 'năm' (year)
Building block for larger numbers
Add 'nghìn' (ngin) for thousand: 'một trăm nghìn' = 100,000

phrases.whenToUse: Asking for or referring to change
phrases.culturalTip: Always count your change—mistakes happen

phrases.whenToUse: Looking for the checkout or payment location
phrases.culturalTip: Some places you pay at table, some at counter

situations.name: Making Friends
situations.description: Moving beyond transactions into genuine connections. These phrases help you build friendships and have real conversations.
situations.culturalNote: Vietnamese people are genuinely curious about foreigners and eager to practice English. Showing interest in their language opens doors to real friendships and incredible experiences.

phrases.culturalTip: Say your name clearly—Vietnamese names are also often nicknames
Follow up by trying to say their name—effort matters
Replace 'Mỹ' with your country: Anh (UK), Úc (Australia), Canada (Canada)
Common small talk—people love talking about their hometowns

phrases.whenToUse: Expressing your appreciation for the country
phrases.culturalTip: Makes people light up with pride—very endearing
Replace 'bia' with 'cà phê' (coffee) for non-drinkers
Coffee dates are the foundation of Vietnamese social life

phrases.english: Can I have your phone number?
phrases.whenToUse: Exchanging contact info with new friends
phrases.culturalTip: Most people use Zalo (like WhatsApp)—ask for that too
Shows you care beyond surface-level conversation

situations.name: Weather & Small Talk
situations.description: Small talk is universal. Weather, observations, and simple conversations help break the ice and practice your Vietnamese.
situations.culturalNote: Weather is a safe topic everywhere. Saigon is hot and humid most of the year, with a rainy season from May to November. Complaining about the heat bonds everyone.

phrases.whenToUse: Commenting on the heat (very common in Saigon)
phrases.culturalTip: Instant bonding—everyone complains about the heat together
Rain conversations lead to shelter-sharing and friendships
Versatile phrase—works for almost anything positive

phrases.vietnamese: Thời tiết hôm nay thế nào?
phrases.pronunciation: Toy tee-et home nai teh now?
phrases.culturalTip: In Saigon, answer is almost always 'hot' or 'rainy'

phrases.whenToUse: When there's a rare cool breeze or AC
phrases.culturalTip: Cool weather is celebrated—treasure those moments
More personal than formal greetings
